title: iPhone 14 Durability Test - APPLE FINALLY FIXED IT ?!
description: FINALLY, we have been waiting YEARS for Apple to fix this. Grab some protection for your phone HERE:  The iPhone 14 might look the same as the iPhone 13. The iPhone 14 might even be the same shape as the 13.  But *inside* the iPhone 14... things are very very different.    Watch the iPhone 14 Teardown HERE:  Get my Shirts and Razor Knife here!    Anker is named as the Official Charging Partner of JerryRigEverything:    *Follow me for updates!* Instagram:  Facebook:  Twitter:   LARGE tool kit:  Travel Tool Kit:  Mega Tool Kit:  Plastic Pry tools:  Metal phone opening tool:  Replacement phone parts:   The camera I used to film this video:  (GH6  The Lens I used for this video:  Wide angle lens:  And this Metabones adapter:  This is the drone I use:   TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.O. Box on my 'About page':   JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: So I've kind of been making fun of iPhones for, like, a really long time. For like basically 10 years now, mostly because they deserved it. But this year, this year is different. Rumor is Apple has finally fixed the worst part of the iPhone design. Yeah, from the outside at first glance, the iPhone 14 looks just like the 13. But the kind folks over at Apple have been working hard all year long changing up the insides. And if the rumors are true this new regular iPhone 14 is the best built iPhone in a really, really, really long time. Really. It's even built better than the more expensive iPhone 14 Pro. I might be getting ahead of myself though. Can't count our chickens before they hatch, nor can we count the apples in a seed. Not sure where I'm going with that one. Let's get started. [Intro] I'm just going to say it. Apple has changed up the new internal structure of the iPhone 14. For the past 9 years, iPhones have been opened up with the screen first, which led to some massive repair problems when they introduced the glued shut impossible to repair glass backed iPhone 8, with repair costs exceeding $500 when the glass cracked, which it often does. Glass is glass a nightmare for wallets everywhere. All of that though has changed with the iPhone 14. Rumor is the screen still comes off on its own for easy replacement of course. But the back glass now does the same. The back panel is easy to replace, and officially, straight from Apple, only costs $169 instead of the normal $500 for the glued together versions like the iPhone 14 Pro. It's cool to see Apple doing something about the situation and I hope it expands into the Pro models. This is a big deal, even more so since the aftermarket non-official glass replacements will usually only cost about $20 or $30. It'll be a game changer for people who like non-broken phones and non-broke wallets. Like I said though, these are just rumors, we won't know for sure until we can tear this down ourselves. But first, the durability test. With a brand new internal design we need to check out the structural integrity. Apple is, of course, using the ceramic shield again which leaves extremely faint lines at level 6, and scratches at a level 7. I do think Apple's Ceramic Shield is an improvement over normal tempered glass. It's nice that it's also protecting the 12 megapixel selfie camera which is right next to the metal earpiece grill. Ceramic Shield though is still solidly a member of the glass family and not invincible. Preemptive protection is always cheaper than having none. On my personal phone I rock protection from my channel's sponsor dbrand. They have a perfectly fit tempered glass screen protector, along with a grip case. The rubberized sides have that sweet micro-dotted texture and the raised lip to keep the camera bump protected. The only thing better than cheaply repairing something is not having it break in the first place. I'll leave a link down in the description. Dbrand.com/14 so you can get your phone protected just like mine. Alright, where were we? Oh yes, the aerospace grade aluminum. Aerospace grade is actual manufacturing terminology, which is a bit more founded than Samsung's Armor Aluminum since Armor is more marketing jargon than a real life substance. Apple uses recycled aluminum in 59% of their products, probably since it's cheaper, but also since it has 1/40th the carbon footprint of mined aluminum...you know, since it's already out of the ground. Plus, Apple buys some of their aluminum from a company in Canada which melts aluminum using hydroelectricity instead of burning fossil fuels, all of which I can get behind. My iPhone 14 is an international version which does include a SIM card tray. Unfortunately the SIM tray is not included in the version headed for the United States. We still have the lightning port at the bottom for the time being. The rumored removable back glass is back here on the back. It'll be fun to tear this one down and see how it looks from the inside. We can make our way over to the camera hump. The iPhone 14 has two cameras back here, along with a circular flash. Not sure if this version has the 9 LEDs inside the flash like the Pro does. We'll have to find out during that same teardown. We have the 12 megapixel normal camera, and the 12 megapixel ultra wide. Apple is again bragging about the sapphire crystal lens cover which is still strange. Sapphire should only start scratching at a level 8 or 9, but as we can see from the scratches at 6, we know Apple ain't using the good stuff. And whatever this is back here honestly just seems to scratch easier than their Ceramic Shield on the front. In my opinion Apple should just ditch their impure sapphire venture and double down on Ceramic Shield which physically appears to be better anyway. Let me know down in the comments if you want to see me test the new Apple Watch Ultra which also is supposedly protected with Apple's low-grade sapphire. We can always check just to be sure. As for the screen we have a 6.1 inch super retina display. And as we can see from the burn test, the pixels start going white after about 20 seconds. And normally I would stop the burning at this point, but I haven't had time to mention the SOS calling, which is actually kind of cool. If the iPhone 14 is out of service, it can like talk to satellites and stuff and get help on the way during an emergency. Apparently though, this is a service and it costs extra money. Apple is providing the subscription for free for the first two years. But if you get lost or aren't subscribed after that, you can just die. I love the burn test. The screen's brightness is permanently damaged after the extended flame sesh, and you can see that the OLED pixels never do recover. Now for the bend test. With the internal redesign on the iPhone 14, the structure needs to be tested. I would hate to have a repeat of the old iPhone 6 days, and not all phones live to the end. However, with this new iPhone 14 bending from the back, we don't have any flex whatsoever. And again from the front, we still have a rock solid sandwich of glass. The iPhone 14 is as structurally sound as last year, even with the new removable panels. Nice work, Apple. Apple's one of the largest and richest corporations on the planet, so the major steps they are taking towards reparability, sustainability, and just keeping their devices around longer gets a thumbs up from me. We'll find out if the rumors are true about that back panel with the teardown. So hit that subscribe button so you don't miss it. Grab a dbrand grip case for whatever phone you're rocking now. Cases do tend to work better before things are broken. And as always, come hang out with me on Instagram and Twitter. And thanks a ton for watching. I'll see you around.
